entry.title: C Extern Function
entry.content:
Here we want to define a function in a C program file and would like to write another C program that can use that function. That kind of function is called extern function, which means the function uses extern keyword.

Here is the tutorial about C Extern funciton/variable.

Below is an example from us. The example is about defining and implementing a random mysql hash key generation method.

Define Extern Function in a Head File

To use functions coming from other libs in C, the most common way is to define those functions in head files, and those head files are used as the entries to use functions defined in them. But only functions with extern keyword can be used by other C programs.

Note that using extern functions are different from implementing extern functions.

Here is the head file hashkeygenerator.h that has the definiton of extern function.

Implement Extern Function in a C File

The function should have an algorithm to generate random hash key, and the implementation should be in the C file.

Here is the C file hashkeygenerator.c in this example:

Now to compile this C file, use following command:

The we will find a hashkeygenerator.o file under the same folder with the head file and C file.

Test the Extern Function

Below is the program to test the extern function above. Note that rand() function will return the same sequence of string if the period between two function calls is too small. Here we make it 10 seconds.

See the code below and the file name is testhashkeygenerator.c:

Now we need to generate an executable file by runing this command:

To run the file, use this command:

And we will see two random hash key as follow:

Here is the link of the three files above in this tutorial.

entry.title: Ruby YAML Summary
entry.content:
YAML is data serialisation language designed to be directly writable and readable by humans. YAML is not a Markup language but a data serialization standard for all programming languages.

Here is the link of YAML Org.
Here is the link of YAML Cookbook for Ruby.

entry.title: Thinking in Number Theory
entry.content:
Number theory problems are very popular in algorithm programming contest. Most of time it is not easy to figure out the solution. Now here we will propose some generic ideas to think through this kind of problems.

This artical will be updated continously.

1. Prime Check

Given an integer, check whether it is a prime or not is a high frequent problem. There are a lot of algorithms to do this check. Some of them are as follows:

  • The naive O(n^1.5) algorithm:

  • Sieve of Eratosthenes.

  • Rabin-Miller primality test algorithm.

Sometimes, we need to figure out all the primes within a specific range. In that case, the second algorithm usually is the best choice, expecially for the problems described in the next sections.

2. Prime Factors

In Number Theory problems, we are ussually asked to figure out the factors of a given integer. In this case, a good idea (not always) is to figure out all its prime factors and their powers. To do that, we need to use (not always) Sieve of Eratosthenes to generate all the primes no larger than given integer. But this solution is not a silver bullet because sometimes the given integer is so large that we do not have enough memory to store all the primes or calculate them within the timebound.

3. Integer Generation

Maybe we find that it is inpractical to divide the given integer into mulplication of primes. Thus, we can try to multiply the primes we have to generate another integer. In this scenario, we do not have to worry about the limited memory to save large number of primes or find all the required primes in a short time. The reason is that even we multiply the same prime for several times (maybe around 30 or even less), we can get a very large integer. Remember, 2^64 = 18446744073709551616 .
entry.summary: Number theory problems are very popular in algorithm programming contest. Most of time it is not easy to figure out the solution. Now her

entry.title: Thinking in Test
entry.content:
This summary may be updated in the future.

We need to follow some steps to test service starting from development to deployment. It is very important because it can help us to find issues and fix them as soon as possible before customer experience become worse.

Roughly, there are maily Four steps in the through test on service. They are tests/verification in (local) development, tests while building service in remote machines, tests in different stages of deployment on remote machines, and manual verification of services on remote machines.

Here are some details of these steps.

Local Tests

When develop service on the local, we need to test it before build and deploy it on remote machines. In local development, at least we need these tests:

  • Unit Tests
  • Integration Tests (Test integration between service and data storage or among different components of the service)
  • Manual Verification

In this step, we need to check test coverage including class coverage, method coverage and line coverage.

Tests While Building Software on Remote Machines

Before we actually deploy service on remote machines, we need to build it. While building service, we need to run the tests which are written in development. These tests are unit tests and integration tests in the last stage.

In this stage, the building process stops if any tests fail.

Tests After Deploying Software on Remote Machines

After deploy service on the remote machines successfully, we need to test the public APIs or performance of the service in all the stages of deployment. Different stages may include Beta stage, Gamma stage, PreProd stage and Prod stage or even more stages.

In these stages, we need to run following tests: Load Tests, Fuzz Tests, Code Review Verification and tests gathering performance statistics.

Manual Verification After Deployment of Remote Machines

Even though we deploy service on remote machines successfully, we still need to manually test the service. One way is to test APIs through Web GUI or Command Line Interface. Besides, we can manually change the data storage or the behaviors of system to simulate real world situation.
entry.summary:
This summary may be updated in the future.

We need to follow some steps to test service starting from development to deployment. I

entry.title: Deploy Cron Job on Mac Tutorial
entry.content:
There are mainly two ways to schedule timed jobs on Mac. One is using cron command. The other is using Mac launchd command.

Here is the Apple developer guide of Timed Jobs Using Cron and Launchd and Creating Launch Daemons and Agents.

And here is a good tutorial about Startingup Jobs with Crontab and Launchd.

This tutorial is about scheduling timed jobs using Launchd and the reason is as follows:

But if we do want to use cron command to startup timed jobs, this link may be helpful.

The basic process is that we need to create a .plist (plist scripts) text file, add timed jobs setting inside the file, put that file under certain directory, and then use launchctl command to start timed jobs.

Choose Timed Jobs Directory

Mac will startup timed jobs that defined in .plist files under certain directories only. Here is the list of those directories:

  • /Library/LaunchDaemons - Put our plist scripts in this folder if our job needs to run even when no users are logged in.
  • /Library/LaunchAgents - Put our plist scripts in this folder if the job is only useful when users are logged in.
  • $HOME/Library/LaunchAgents - Put our plist files in this folder if the job is only useful when users are logged in.

Note that we need to use sudo command if we want to put plist scripts under first two directories.

Here we plan to create a plist script under /Library/LaunchDaemons. So run this command:

Create a plist Script

We had better follow Apple’s documentation to name the plist script as it can help to avoid namespace collisions. Run following command:

Here is content of the plist script above:

Here is the content of helloworld.sh .

The plist means running a timed jobs Run the script /Absolute/Path/To/helloworld.sh every 60 seconds and redirect the standard output and standard error as shown.

Deploy Timed Jobs

Use following command to deploy timed job:

After one or more minutes, we execute this command to check job status:

If we want to cancel the timed job, just run this command:
entry.summary: There are mainly two ways to schedule timed jobs on Mac. One is using cron command. The other is using Mac launchd

entry.title: Java Immutable Class QuickStart
entry.content:
Here is the official website of Java Immutable Class, benefits of Immutable Class and Getstarted Tutorial.

Generally, the benefits of Immutable class is:

  • Create thread-safe objects.
  • Easy to make program parallel.
  • Keep the internal program state consistent.
  • Cache the references to immutable objects.

Now below it is our quickstart tutorial.

Setup Environment

Here we suggest to use IntelliJ IDE because this IDE is easy to generate immutable class.

Here is the official tutorial to enable annotations for immutable class feature.

Create Java Project

In IntelliJ, create a Java Maven Project. This part will be provided later as it should be very easy.

Below is the project basic settings:

Enable Annotations

Open IntelliJ system preferences panel and edit the settings as follows:

  • Check Enable annotation processing
  • Check Module content root
  • Edit Production sources directory as generated
  • Edit Test sources directory as generated_test

Write Java Code

Here is the link of Github Repository of this tutorial project.

Here is the content of pom.xml

Then create a package with this path: blogrunner/src/main/java/com/yulartech/domain and class called Blog.java.

Here is the code.

Now we build the project inside IntelliJ, and then we can find the generated immutable class under this path target/generated-sources/annotations/com/yulartech/domain/ImmutableBlog.java.

Now here is the class containing main function:

Build and Run the Project

Now again we build the project. This step is optional.

Then right click the main function and choose the Run App.main() option. We will see the output as follows:
entry.summary: Here is the official website of Java Immutable Class
